 What I have in bold and italic is my exact question. Why doesn't anyone care about an ant dying? If someone wants to perform an abortion, everyone will fight to stop it. If someone like Schiavo requested to die, no one wants her to. They don't know her, they don't know the fetus, and they don't know the ant. Here are my thoughts on the issue.
 
 
 Basically a long time ago we didn't have any laws and it was complete anarchy (this is an assumption). We would fight each other for food, shelter, clothes, and other necessities. Finally we got the idea that if we just worked together we could provide for everyone and not worry about dying (we are also assuming that everyone has an instinct to want to be alive themself). So we decided to set laws saying that no one could kill the others, so murder became wrong. Likewise, the same sort of things happened with stealing, rape, and any other crime. They became wrong because if we did them other people would do them to us so we agree to stop so they will stop. Since we can't communicate with animals such as ants we don't have an agreement with them. If we kill an ant there is no consequence, so we don't think twice. So now after all these millions of years like that with no killing we have ingrained in our heads "MURDER IS WRONG". Vengance is still an instinct however so it sort of overrides the murder thought when the death penalty comes in for some people. Because of the reasoning behind our agreement, people decided that the reason they don't kill is they wouldn't want to be killed. So they think of if they were the fetus and they think "I would want to live" so they are against abortion. Not many people can put themselves in the shoes of the ants, but we still have some who would never hurt a fly or an ant. This is my theory anyway.
 
 And I would like to hear what your opinion is even if it's not an option on the poll.

Nurglitch

Modern_Republic: I think you're missing Adept's point about counters. In this case he's using a counter-argument called "reductio ad absurdem", a reduction of an argument to absurdity by proposing a formally equivalent but contradictory statement. 
 
 The problem with your argument (rhetorical question really) is that it appeals to an intuition, that we care more about a human baby than two mice. Adept's counter-argument appeals to an intuition as well, that we care more about a favoured dog than a convicted rapist. Your implied conclusion, that a human life is more valuable than an animal's, contradicts Adept's implied conclusion that an animal's life is more valuable than a human's. 
 
 Adept's got an interesting point about moral proximity, particularly with regards to the ethic of care as it is discussed here in terms of abortion. The idea of moral proximity is the more distant an action is from us, the less we care about it. Conversely the closer an action is to us, the more we care about it. Many people find this intuitively appealing because they have the intuition that you should treat those closest to you best, that you should accord your comrades a status of moral priviledge. 
 
 This moral proximity seems to make sense if we assume, for example, that it is true that you should feed your own starving children first. Obviously there's a problem here if it's to be used to answer the question: "Why is abortion worse than killing any other living thing?", because to many people abortions are far more abstractly related to their lives than their pets are. In order to say abortion is worse than killing any other living thing, we need an explanation that doesn't turn on whether we care about things in order to explain their objective value.

Iuris

Ah, a true phylosophical debate.
 
 Myself, I consider myself an empirist/materialist, si I do not believe in the existence of the abstract. Thus, from the research for my graduation thesis, which the origin of the state monopoly over physical force, it would appear that:
 -state apparatus was established by the ruler to enforce his will (instituting the monopoly to remove threats to his power)
 -initially, this did not recognize any rights beyont the universal right of the ruler (quod principi placet, legis habet virtutem)
 -as the only source of physical force, the ruler was eventually forced to enforce the interests of the subjects, establishing codes of law and/or judges, who established "minor" rights
 -in course of time, the ruler's power was challenged and curtailed by constitutions
 
 So we see that these rights are actually not very old. Constitutional rights specifically are almost exclusively developped as a reaction to abuses of power.
 
 Two little curiosities: 
 
 In Ancient Rome, right of life was not absolute. The Pater familias had the right to execute his slaves and children and even wives vitae necisque potestas. Even so, the society thrived and the right was rarely used.
 
 In Ancient Rome, you had the provision demanding the execution of deformed children. And yet, the fetus has a very limited right: it was entitled to inherit in case it was born alive. An interesting arrangement, concerning our debates 'round here...

 So for most people, it's not a clear cut case of people being more important than other creatures, or all people being equally important. Not really, once they take a moment of introspection.  Legally, perhaps not. Morally I would have no hesitation in killing someone I though was suffering needlessly in the same way I will put down an animal that is in pain.

Even so, your dog isn't worth the collar it wears when compared to the intrinsic priceless worth of another human being.

The alternative is to say that you zachvac are a worthless priceless valueless meaningless piece of wart on the face of this accidental uncomely chance blob of a universe, and gnojek's dog isn't worth the collar it wears and neither are you or gnojek.
 
 I think cone's perspective is the most beneficial for society. If the members of a society recognizes/places intrinsic value in one another then the society will thrive.

 
 Or the alternative could be that the value of your life is what you make of it. If you live your life killing and raping other people, I would tend to say your life was not worth as much as someone who helped homeless people and charities as a volunteer. Of course the value of a life is subjective, so there is no actual value of a human. Also, you can't measure a dog's value to a human's value. Some people think the dog is worth nothing, while to some people the human is worth more (probably people close to the human). But you can't make a subjective statement that the human's life is worth more than the dog's life. (well you can it's just not accurate)
zachvac

You care to present some data that shows that there is a better chance that a dog will grow up to be nice than a human will?
 

 That's not what I said, I said "more people die from guns (used by people) than dog bites. The original person said there was a better chance, so it still stands." If you really want me to I think I can come up with data showing more deaths from humans than from dog bites.
 
 

 We of course are talking about born infants, not "babies." He said he'd save a newborn baby over a puppy. But since the baby really has no conciousness, we should save the puppy? Obviously not, so that can't be the reason either.

 Look, he cites as one of his reasons that he would save a puppy over a human infant is that Notice he thinks that we have too many humans as it is...this means we have too many humans even with the current abortion laws in place. 
 

 Not just he thinks, it's fact. We are getting overpopulated. More people are being born than are dying, so the population is increasing. At the same time we are not acquiring more land to live on so we are getting more and more overpopulated.
 

 In other words, he thinks an extra step (in addition to abortion) needs to be taken in order to decrease the surplus population. 
 

 He never said that and neither did I, just that there is an overpopulation problem even with abortion. No one said anything about solving the problem.
 
 

 Therefore, one of his justifications for saving a puppy over an infant is to decrease the surplus population. If he is for eliminating infants for this reason, why wouldn't he be for eliminating people via wars or the death penalty?

 The point was that there is a choice, you can save the infant and add to the population or save the dog and help the population while getting a really good pet. It's not like he chose to murder the infant, he just chose the dog over the human, in this instance he thought the dog had more value than the human (see my response to chloe)
Cone

If you really want me to I think I can come up with data showing more deaths from humans than from dog bites.

 Even if this were true, it would not matter. It would obviously be the case that those humans that killed other humans adopted the following view of life:
...the value of a life is subjective, so there is no actual value of a human.

 Thus, those humans that killed other humans determined that it was of higher value to rid the world of that particular human than to keep them around. Why should we fault them for making this decision? After all, 
you can't make a subjective statement that the human's life is worth more than the dog's life.

 And neither can you make the subjective statement that a human is better off alive than dead or has a right to remain alive when others wish him to be dead.
 
 
Not just he thinks, it's fact. We are getting overpopulated. More people are being born than are dying, so the population is increasing. At the same time we are not acquiring more land to live on so we are getting more and more overpopulated.

 No, zachvac. You have it wrong. First you have to prove that we currently are overpopulated before you can say that we are becoming even more overpopulated. You are begging the question.
 
 
He never said that and neither did I, just that there is an overpopulation problem even with abortion. No one said anything about solving the problem.

 There is no overpopulation problem.
 
 
The point was that there is a choice, you can save the infant and add to the population or save the dog and help the population while getting a really good pet. It's not like he chose to murder the infant, he just chose the dog over the human, in this instance he thought the dog had more value than the human (see my response to chloe)

 It's unlikely that feeding one little infant to the dogs will help the surplus population problem you seem to think exists. If we are becoming more and more overpopulated by the day (as the question-begging claim you made stated), it wouldn't be because we are gaining one or two more humans than are dying; it would be because we are gaining thousands or tens of thousands more people than the amount that are dying. Thus, feeding one infant to the dogs will do nothing to help the fanciful overpopulation problem you think factually exists.
 
 I will suggest one (actually the only) plausible way to solve the purported (though incorrect) overpopulation problem. We can set some factors that would encompass vast amounts of people (such as skin-color, nationality, eye-color, etc.), gather all who possess these factors into centralized locations, and starve, gas, and burn them to death. This would most certainly solve the population crisis we face today as it would rid the world of millions, tens of millions, even hundreds of millions of resource-taking human beings. This would certainly bring the birth-rate-to-death-rate ratio back into balance. In short, one citing that he saved a puppy instead of a human infant in order to decrease the surplus population is flat out stupid.
 
 When one wishes to save a puppy over a human infant, he shouldn't try to hide behind some false justification. He should just tell us the real reason why he would save the puppy over the human infant. Instead of saying "I was just trying to help out the overpopulation problem," he should say "Human beings have no value whatsoever, and thus, a human being does not deserve to be treated any better than a dog. Since a human being doesn't have any value, (and certainly no more than a dog) I chose to save the puppy rather than the human because I needed a pet, not a child."

 Murder is illegal. Abortion isn't. Therfore, abortion is not murder. A semantic point, I know, but one should always strive to be as accurate as possible.
 
 
 
 Legally, perhaps not. Morally I would have no hesitation in killing someone I though was suffering needlessly in the same way I will put down an animal that is in pain.

 I don't care about that guy. He should be able to take care of himself without my help. My dog, on the other hand, is my dependent, and had little choice in that situation.

 You can "view" it as whatever you want. Murder is illegal killing. It's not killing you don't like, or that you view as unjust, it is only killing which is illegal. Abortion is legal, hence not murder.
 
 
How do you know they don't want to suffer? If someone is dying from Cancer maybe they want to die from the cancer so someone can study his/her body....You believe in a "right to personal autonomy" yet you wish to make decisions about someone elses body?????!!!!!

 http://www.4forums.com/political/showpost.php?p=137833&postcount=291
Adept

wait a second... you put personal autonomy over any the "obligation to support others"....so if that mom wants to kill that baby she should have that right over any option to remove it and save its life....can you explain?

 
 I'll try.
 
 The mom has the right to do whatever she wants with her own body. If she wants, she can remove her support from the baby whenever she wishes. At many stages of the pregnancy, to do this means to kill the baby. However, at later stages the baby is capable of surviving outside of the womb. In such instances where the mother no longer wants to support the baby, but the baby is capable of surviving outside of the womb, I feel that non-lethal mthods of abortion (basically a premature C-section birth) should be made available.
 
 This respects the womans right to not support the baby against her will, and provides the potential for the baby to live despite that.
 
 Of course, if the woman is adamant she doesn't want a c-section and would prefer an abortion the 'regular' way, then that is her choice and I would respect that while disagreeing with it.
Winston Smith

Yes. The Bible paints the picture of human beings as created in the image of God, the only creatures enjoying this distinction. However, this may not be the only reason one believes, as you put it, humans are superior to other animals.

 
 If dogs had written the bible instead of humans, I'll bet God would look like a dog, (I hope like my two German shepherds). Of course humans have superior intelligence but still I'd save the puppy from the oncoming truck rather than the human baby. I am of the same opinion as gnojek.

 So tell me. Where is it outlined that God (any god will do) gave us the right to have dominion over all the earth?
 
 And importantly, where is this point outlined in multiple objective third-party sources from the same era, and which modern studies published in peer-reviewed publications support it?
 
 If you want to use the Bible (or any religious text, for that matter) as a template for society, then you have to prove, beyond a shadow of a doubt that it is true. Not that you believe in it, not that it might be true, not that other people think it's true and certainly not that the people who wrote it think it is true. You have to prove that it is the only possible literal truth.
 
 And good luck with that.
